data.title: I had serious jaw surgery â€” and they refused to give me pain meds
data.description:
Years ago, IÂ wrote about the opioid crisis and the dangers of punishing legitimate pain patients in our rush to address addiction. I warned that we were reacting too strongly to the problem, swinging too far in the opposite direction.

I never imagined I would become an exhibit for that warning.

I recently underwent extensive maxillofacial surgery â€” jaw bone removal for osteomyelitis. The doctor even said, â€œYouâ€™ll be in real painâ€ â€” thatâ€™s when you know itâ€™s gonna be bad. My surgeonâ€™s office called the day before to go over my pre-operative care and also to inform me they would not be prescribing any opioid pain medication.

Why not? Because I had an existing prescription for a different opioid â€” even though it was one that had run out and was sitting, unused, in a medicine cabinet at my parentâ€™s house four states away. They told me to â€œjust use thatâ€ for my post-surgical pain.

Never mind that the other opioid medication had been prescribed at a very specific dose for a completely different reason. Never mind that I was going to be in severe pain after having my jaw reconstructed. The answer was no.

When I pushed back, they made me feel like I was drug-seeking simply for asking for appropriate post-surgical pain management.

I am not the first person to have such a thing happen. After I wrote a piece about this six years ago I received many emails from readers who had received similar treatment â€” even people undergoing terminal cancer. Recently, a close friend â€” a prominent plastic surgeon who has spent her career caring for patients â€” developed a severe infection in her wisdom teeth. She too was denied stronger pain medication. Let me repeat that â€” a prominent plastic surgeon who clearly understands pain management was told simply, â€œTake ibuprofen.â€

This is medical malpractice hiding behind the guise of policy for good.

I know the opioid crisis is devastatingly real. I live in West Virginia, a state that has been devastated by opiates. In 2025, approximately 73,000 Americans died from opioid overdoses. But the data tell that these deaths are not coming from your surgeonâ€™s prescription pad.

According to the CDC, 92 percent of opioid overdose deaths involved synthetic opioids â€” that is, illicitly manufactured fentanyl and street drugs. Prescription opioid deaths have been rapidly declining for years, dropping to around 13,000 in 2023 and remaining relatively stable.

In the U.S., if fentanyl involvement in overdoses had remained constant rather than skyrocketing, we would have approximatelyÂ 260,000 more deceased people living among us today â€” about four times the number who attended the Super Bowl in person this year.

You want to know whatâ€™s killing us? In 2024,Â 22,000 lbsÂ of fentanyl was seized at U.S. borders. For context, just two milligrams of fentanyl â€” an amount that fits on the tip of a pencil â€” is enough to be lethal. So the amount seized is the equivalent of 5 billion lethal doses â€” enough to kill every man, woman, and child in the U.S. 15 times over. And that is just what was seized â€” much more gets through each year.

The Centers for Disease Control guidelinesÂ acknowledgeÂ that its recommendations have been misapplied in harmful ways, including â€œrigid application of opioid dosage thresholdsâ€ and actions that â€œcontributed to patient harm, including untreated and undertreated pain, serious withdrawal symptoms, worsening pain outcomes, psychological distress, overdose, and suicidal ideation and behavior.â€

Whatâ€™s really happening is that doctors are terrified, and they are hurting people because of it.

We have created a system where doctors are more afraid of prescribing appropriately than they are of leaving patients to suffer. They are scared scrutiny from federal authorities and state medical board investigators. They fear being labeled as â€œpill millâ€ doctors. They have watched colleagues face prosecution and they have reacted by taking the safest route â€” prescribing nothing or prescribing inadequately.

Meanwhile, assumptions that appropriate prescribing will lead to addiction is totally unproven. Studies show that roughlyÂ 94 percent of patientsÂ donâ€™t even try to refill their opioid prescriptions. They take what they need, and then they stop.

When I left the surgeonâ€™s office, groggy from the anaesthesia, jaw throbbing, being told I couldnâ€™t have appropriate pain medication, I thought about the thousands of patients going through the same thing â€” sent home from surgery, from emergency rooms, from dental procedures, to suffer needlessly because we have overcorrected.

The opioid crisis is real. The prescription-to-addiction pipeline was real and required intervention. But we have now created a new crisis in the form of systematic undertreatment of acute pain in America. We have turned appropriate medical care into a guilty act.

What about the elderly woman after hip replacement or the construction worker after a serious accident? They suffer in silence, told their pain â€œisnâ€™t that badâ€ or that they should â€œtough it out.â€

This isnâ€™t health care. It is abandonment.

The data are clear: prescription opioids are not driving the overdose crisis. Illicit fentanyl is. And itâ€™s time we direct our outrage and resources toward the flood of deadly synthetic opioids pouring across our borders from abroad. Because right now, weâ€™re fighting yesterdayâ€™s war while innocent patients pay the price.

Liberty Vittert is a professor of data science at Washington University in St. Louis and the resident on-air statistician for NewsNation, a sister company of The Hill.

data.title: Where things stand in Texas ahead of the primary
data.description:
Morning Report is The Hillâ€™s a.m. newsletter. Subscribe here.

In todayâ€™s issue:

â–ªÂ Texas primaries in home-stretch

â–ª Bill Clinton sets precedent with testimony

â–ª Netflix out, paving Paramount takeover of WBD

â–ª Pentagonâ€™s war of words against Anthropic

President Trump heads to Texas today amid final campaigning in two of the countryâ€™s most closely watched electoral contests before midterm primaries in the Lone Star State next week.

Texasâ€™s elections kick off a series of primaries throughout the country over the next six months, and the marquee Senate battle is capturing the political spotlight.

The race has already set a record as the most expensive Senate primary in U.S. history, with $110 million spent in campaign advertising. Most of that spending has been on the GOP side.

Polling shows a close race among the three Republican candidates, with Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton holding a slight lead in the Decision Desk HQ (DDHQ) polling average, an advantage heâ€™s held for months over incumbent Sen. John Cornyn (R). Paxton is narrowly ahead in the average with 36.5 percent support, closely followed by Cornyn with 32.2 percent and Rep. Wesley Hunt (R) in third with 18 percent.

On the Democratic side, state Rep. James Talarico and Rep. Jasmine Crockett are neck and neckÂ in the DDHQ polling average, with 44.4 percent support for Talarico to Crockettâ€™s 44.1 percent.

But polling has been much more limited than on the Republican side. A few of the polls have also been affiliated with a campaign or its supporters, including a few showing Talarico ahead, and are viewed with some skepticism as to their reliability.

Cornyn is locked in the race of his political life as he tries to fend off primary challenges from Paxton and Hunt. Both have sought to brand the GOP senator as a â€œRINO,â€ or Republican in name only, and as insufficiently supportive of the president, while Cornyn has pushed back in stressing his conservative bona fides.

Although Cornyn has been an institution unto himself in Texas politics, having served in his Senate seat for more than two decades, he faces a significant uphill battle to clinching renomination.

Texas election law requires a candidate to receive a majority of the vote to win a primary outright, so the top two candidates appear almost certain to advance to a runoff in May.

The race has gotten increasingly intense as the primary approaches, though Cornyn and Paxton are longtime rivals and have been trading barbs with each other for months.

Cornyn has attacked Paxton for various controversies concerning both his public and private life, including an indictment on security fraud charges he faced and an unsuccessful impeachment effort over accusations of bribery. The indictment was dismissed after he reached a deal with prosecutors to pay restitution.

Paxton has hit back at Cornyn for a few instances in which the senator broke with his party, including when he supported former President Bidenâ€™s bipartisan gun safety law passed after the Uvalde, Texas, shooting, and he accused him of being disloyal to Trump.

But Cornynâ€™s campaign escalated its offensive on Paxton to a new level this week in slamming him over an alleged extramarital affair. Paxton and his wife are currently in the process of getting a divorce.

â€œUnlike John Cornyn, whoâ€™s become a desperate shell of a man clinging to power, my campaign is not about attacking someone elseâ€™s family,â€ Paxton said in a post on the social platform X, including a new ad of his own featuring his daughter praising him and his values.

The remaining X factor in the race is whether the president will weigh in to give what would likely be a highly influential endorsement to any candidate. Heâ€™s previously praised all three candidates but hasnâ€™t revealed any preference.

Trumpâ€™s visit to Corpus Christi, Texas, today is on official business, but political observers will be watching for any hint of whom he may be supporting next week, The Hillâ€™s Julia Mueller and Julia Manchester report.

â–ª Politico: Republicans freaking out over Texas race.

Meanwhile, Crockett and Talarico, who are both seen as rising stars within the Democratic Party, are battling for the chance to pull off what would be a major upset in the general election.

Texas has consistently voted Republican for years on the federal and state level, but both candidates have expressed optimism about the chances of flipping it blue, though theyâ€™d have different approaches in doing so.

Crockett has gained national attention for her strong pushback against Trump and his Republican allies, sometimes using catchy phrases that go viral online. One of the most prominent instances came in 2024 during a faceoff with former Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.).

Talarico, a Presbyterian seminarian, has taken a different approach, seeking to present a more conciliatory message to those who may have voted for Trump and other Republicans in the past.

The race became heated earlier this month over comments Talarico allegedly made about Crockett and former Rep. Colin Allred (D-Texas).

Polls have shown a tight race, with Crockett leading in a few of the most recent public, independent polls.

One important factor will be how much Talaricoâ€™s appearance on Stephen Colbertâ€™s â€œLate Showâ€ and the controversy surrounding the decision not to air it on television will affect the race.

Talarico saw a significant fundraising boost following the interview, which aired on YouTube, and polling since then has been limited.

With only two major candidates in the Democratic race, one is likely to get more than 50 percent support and clinch the nomination, preventing a runoff.

Both candidates have argued their approach is the right one to give Democrats a fighting chance in Texas. The time to choose one of two significantly diverging paths arrives Tuesday.

â–ª The Hill: Cardi B tells followers to support Crockett.

Smart Take with Blake Burman

In a surprise to reporters in Chappaqua, N.Y., last night, Hillary Clinton spoke after her deposition with the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee and even took reportersâ€™ questions. Clinton maintained she â€œdid not know Jeffrey Epsteinâ€ and criticized the committee for asking about other issues, including UFOs. I asked Richard Goodstein, a former Clinton adviser, what he thinks former President Clinton might say today.Â 

â€œLook, Epstein was a donor to Democratic causes, so he ended up, youâ€™d see pictures of him in the White House when Clinton was there. I had pictures like that too. And then he took Epsteinâ€™s plane on these foundation missions. Thatâ€™s what heâ€™s going to say,â€ Goodstein told me.

After months of negotiations, the Clintons called for their testimony to be public. Given we saw Hillary Clinton go before reporters, youâ€™d have to imagine the former president follows suit. No matter what happens today, the videos of the depositions are expected in the coming days.

Burman hosts â€œThe Hillâ€ weeknights, 6p/5c on NewsNation.

3 Things to Know Today

  1. Paramount has won the battle to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery after Netflix said it wouldnâ€™t match the companyâ€™s bid. The merger now will need approval from the Department of Justice to go through.
  2. At least two individuals involved in the shooting with Cuban forces on Wednesday were U.S. citizens, a U.S. official told The Hillâ€™s sister network NewsNation. One individual died, while the other was injured.
  3. Pakistan has declared â€œopen warâ€Â on Afghanistan after the Pakistani defense minister saidÂ patience has â€œrun outâ€Â on repeated attacks by Afghan forces and the Pakistani Taliban. Pakistan launched a series of airstrikes in various regions of Afghanistan in response.

Leading the Day

SETTING PRECEDENT: House Democrats are eyeing precedent being set Friday when former President Clinton testifies in the Oversight and Government Reform Committeeâ€™s investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.

While itâ€™s unclear how much Clinton will have to say about the investigation itself, Democrats have not hidden the fact they believe receiving testimony from a former president will help pave the path to eventually bring Trump before Congress, especially under a future Democratic House majority.

Democrats arenâ€™t wasting any time in making the argument.

â€œThis committee has now set a new precedent about talking to presidents and former presidents,â€ Rep. Robert Garcia (Calif.), the top Democrat on the Oversight panel, told reportersÂ Thursday. â€œWeâ€™re demanding immediately that we ask President Trump to testify in front of our committee and be deposed in front of Oversight Republicans and Democrats.â€

Trump was subpoenaed in the investigation of the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol riot, but the subpoena was later withdrawn. Democrats, many of whom supported requiring Clinton to testify, hope Fridayâ€™s testimony will help compel Trump to testify in future investigations whenever Democrats retake the House and get subpoena power again.

A former president testifying before Congress is not entirely unprecedented, but is extremely rare. The last president to do so was Gerald Ford, who appeared for the noncontroversial topic of celebrating the bicentennial of the Constitution in the 1980s.

Clintonâ€™s agreement to sit for a deposition came after an extensive back-and-forth that he and his wife, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, had with committee Chair James Comer (R-Ky.).

Although the Clintons said they didnâ€™t have any additional information to share relevant to the panelâ€™s investigation, Comer and the committee went forward with a threat to hold them in contempt to compel their testimony.

After it became clear that the full House was likely to pass the contempt resolutions, the Clintons reversed course and agreed.

Though Bill Clintonâ€™s name has appeared in some documents from the Epstein files, he hasnâ€™t been accused of any wrongdoing.

Hillary Clinton said during her testimony before the committee Thursday that she had no information to share about the criminal activities of Epstein and his associate Ghislaine Maxwell and doesnâ€™t remember ever meeting Epstein.

Meanwhile, Republican senators are pressuring the Department of Justice (DOJ) to release all the files related to Epstein following multiple reports that some documents have remained concealed, The Hillâ€™s Alexander Bolton reports. This is despite top DOJ leaders saying last month that they released all documents required under the law.

The documents seemingly include FBI interviews with a woman who accused Trump of sexually assaulting her decades ago.

â–ª The Hill: The new Epstein files controversy, explained.

â–ª The Hill: Comer says Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick may be called to testify.

â–ªÂ The New York Times:Â World Economic Forum head steps down over Epstein ties.

â–ªÂ The New York Times:Â Cooperating witnesses exposed in Epstein files.

ANOTHER DRONE SHOT DOWN: The U.S. military has shot down a Customs and Border Protection drone with a laser in Texas,Â causing the closure of airspaceÂ near the U.S.-Mexico border.

This is second such incident involving a laser fired in Texas that prompted the closure of nearby airspace after an instance earlier this month in which the air traffic from the El Paso airport was briefly shut down for a few hours.

PROGRESS MADE? Omani Foreign Minister Badr al-Busaidi said U.S. and Iranian officials made â€œsignificant progressâ€ in their talks to avoid a military conflict and reach a deal on Iranâ€™s nuclear program.

The officials met Thursday for the most recent round of discussions in Geneva, Switzerland, as the Trump administration considers the possibility of a strike on Iran if diplomacy fails. Oman has served as a mediator in the talks.

Al-Busaidi said both sides will consult with their respective capitals, but technical discussions are expected to continue next week in Vienna. Trump has said he would prefer a diplomatic solution while refusing to take the possibility of a military strike off the table.

House Democrats will force a vote next week to curb Trumpâ€™s authority to attack Iran without congressional authorization. But the resolution is expected to fail in the face of widespread opposition from most Republicans and a handful of Democrats.

â–ª The Hill: Senate GOP leader says any strike on Iran should cause regime change.

WALTZ ON: A federal judge declined to pause the presidentâ€™s construction of a ballroom in the East Wing of the White House, ruling against preservationists who sued to block it, at least for now.

U.S. District Judge Richard Leon ruled against the National Trust for Historic Preservation on the grounds that it didnâ€™t properly challenge the $400 million project, but he said he would reevaluate if the organization amended its complaint.

The trust and the government originally focused on Trumpâ€™s authority to tear down the East Wing and construct a new one, but Leon ruled the preservationists failed to bring the proper claim to test Trumpâ€™s authority to proceed without congressional approval.

â€œTo be fair, the Presidentâ€™s source of legal authority to construct the ballroom was not apparent before the National Trust brought its motion,â€ Leon wrote.

Trump praised the ruling in a post on Truth Social, calling it â€œgreat newsâ€ for the country and White House.

â–ª The Hill: Admin asks court to end temporary protections for Syrians.

MORTGAGE RATE DROP: Mortgage rates fell below 6 percent for the first time in more than three years, giving homebuyers a key opening.

The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage averaged 5.98 percent on Thursday, a drop of 0.03 points from last week, according to Freddie Mac. The development comes as inflation also fell to 2.4 percent last month, slightly lower than economists were expecting.

Trump touted falling mortgage rates in his State of the Union address Tuesday.

Housing sales remained at a 30-year low last year, continuing a steady annual decline dating back to 2022.

â–ª The New York Times: Housing market tilting back toward buyers.

When & Where

  • The president will travel to Corpus Cristi, Texas, where he will receive an energy briefing at 4:05 p.m. and deliver remarks on energy at 4:35 p.m. He will participate in a local TV interview later and then depart to go to Palm Beach, Fla. for the weekend.
  • The House and Senate wonâ€™t meet today.

Zoom In

â€˜GOD COMPLEXâ€™: A top Pentagon official lashed out at Anthropic on Thursday night after the company rejected an ultimatum from officials to agree to terms on the use of its AI model, Claude.

Defense SecretaryÂ Pete HegsethÂ gave a deadline of Friday afternoon for Anthropic to agree to the departmentâ€™s terms or risk a $200 million contract being canceled. But Anthropic CEOÂ Dario AmodeiÂ said the company wouldnâ€™t agree and hopes the Pentagon changes its position.

The company and the Pentagon have beenÂ engaged in a standoffÂ over the use of Claude. The firmâ€™s policy prohibits the usage of ClaudeÂ for mass surveillance orÂ to developÂ weapons that can be used without human oversight.Â 

But the Pentagon has insisted that Anthropic agree to the terms, whichÂ would allowÂ the Pentagon to use the firmâ€™sÂ AI models for â€œall lawful uses.â€

Following Amodeiâ€™s announcement, Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering Emil Michael slammed the tech CEO as a â€œliarâ€ with a â€œGod-complex.â€

â€œHe wants nothing more than to try to personally control the US Military and is ok putting our nationâ€™s safety at risk,â€Â he said in aÂ post on X.Â â€œTheÂ @DeptofWarÂ will ALWAYS adhere to the law but not bend to whims of any one for-profit tech company.â€

â€œNot hard to believe that â¦@AnthropicAIâ© dropped their own safety policy but thinks they should dictate ours,â€Â he said inÂ another post, linking to a story about Anthropic removing a central safety pledge.

The Pentagon warned Anthropic on Tuesday that it could invoke the Defense Production ActÂ (DPA),Â which gives the president widespread authority to control domestic industries for national defense.

ExpertsÂ told The Hillâ€™s Julia Shapero and Filip TimotijaÂ that invoking the DPA on Anthropic would be unusual andÂ isnâ€™tÂ what the law was intended for.

â–ª The Hill: Pentagon removes director of Joint Staff.

â–ª The Hill: Instagram launches new child safety tool.

Elsewhere

STUDENT RELEASED: A Columbia University student has been released after being detained by federal agents who entered a residential building under false pretenses.

Columbia said Thursday that federal immigration authorities detained the student, identified as senior Ellie Aghayeva, after misrepresenting their purpose for entering the building.

â€œOur understanding at this time is that the federal agents made misrepresentations to gain entry to the building to search for a â€˜missing person,â€™â€ acting university President Claire Shipman said in a statement.

Aghayeva later posted on her Instagram story that the Department of Homeland Security â€œillegally arrested meâ€ and asked for help.

But Aghayeva was let go after New York City Mayor Zohran Mamdani (D) expressed concerns to Trump during a meeting, and the president said she would be released â€œimminently.â€

Columbia said it doesnâ€™t allow federal agents into nonpublic buildings without a warrant.

While the situation has seemingly been defused, itâ€™s the latest incident in a series of controversial arrests at academic institutions, including the detainment of Columbia graduate Mahmoud Khalil last year.

â–ª The Hill: High school walkouts over immigration enforcement stir debates.

OLYMPIC CONTROVERSY: A joke by the president to the U.S. menâ€™s Olympic hockey team is sparking pushback online and from at least one player of the womenâ€™s team.

Trump called the menâ€™s team after they won the gold medal at the games last weekend, inviting them to the White House. He said he would have to invite the womenâ€™s team, which also won gold, as well and would be impeached if he didnâ€™t do so, eliciting laughter from the menâ€™s team.

Hilary Knight, the captain of the womenâ€™s team,Â told reportersÂ she thought the joke was â€œdistasteful and unfortunate.â€ She said it shouldnâ€™t overshadow the teamâ€™s accomplishments.

Meanwhile, another controversy is brewing, concerning aÂ doctored TikTok video sharedÂ by the White House that made it seem like menâ€™s hockey playerÂ Brady Tkachuk was disparaging Canadians after winning the gold medal. Tkachuk pushed back, saying he wouldnâ€™t say what the video portrayed him saying.

Opinion

  • Americans donâ€™t need announcements, they need lower drug prices, Sen. Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.) writes in The Hill.
  • Orban and Fico: Putinâ€™s NATO pawns, Mark Toth and Jonathan Sweet write in The Hill.

The Closer

And finally â€¦ ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ Congrats to this weekâ€™s Morning Report quiz winners! They knew their stuff about the history of the presidentâ€™s annual speech to Congress.

Hereâ€™s who went 4/4: Richard Baznik, Stan Wasser, Michael Salanik, Chuck Schoenenberger, Melissa McBurney, Rick Schmidtke, Carmine Petracca, Jess Elger, Pam Manges, Linda L. Field, William Chittam, Jenessa Wagner, Luther Berg, Ned Sauthoff, William Moore, John Ciorciari, Robert Bradley, Mark R. Williamson, Sari Wisch, Steve James and Savannah Petracca.

Woodrow Wilson restored the custom of the president delivering the State of the Union speech in person before Congress when he took office in 1913. Every president has delivered an in-person address since then.

Trump surpassed the previous record held by Bill Clinton, who spoke for about one hour and 29 minutes in his 2000 address. Trump also surpassed his own record from last year for longest congressional address, which was about 100 minutes. The first address by the president to Congress technically isnâ€™t considered a State of the Union.

Ronald Reagan was the only president listed who never gave a response to a State of the Union. Gerald Ford, George H.W. Bush, Bill Clinton and Joe Biden all gave a response before eventually becoming president and giving the address themselves.

The secretary of Interior has most commonly been the designated survivor at seven times. The secretaries of Veterans Affairs and Agriculture are tied for second with six times each.

data.title: Some Republicans increasingly frustrated stock trading ban touted by Trump is stalled
data.description:
Some House Republicans are growing increasingly frustrated with leadership for not moving the ball quickly enough on a stock trading ban, an issue that has vexed Congress for years despite repeated bipartisan calls for reform.

Last month, the House Administration Committee advanced a bill by Chairman Bryan Steil (R-Wis.) that would allow members of Congress, their spouses and their dependent children to hold onto the stocks they already own but prevent them from buying new ones. No action, however, has been taken on the bill since.

And the lack of movement has pushed some rank-and-file Republicans to renew calls for a stock trading ban, especially after President Trump urged Congress to pass legislation on the matter during his State of the Union address Tuesday night.

â€œIf you have a strong bipartisan majority in Congress (supporting the issue), if you have overwhelming support from the public. You have the president of the United States specifically referencing it in the State of the Union, why pray tell is it not put on the floor?â€ Rep. Brian Fitzpatrick (R-Pa.) said.

He added that a stock trading ban is long â€œoverdue.â€

â€œItâ€™s very frustrating,â€ Fitzpatrick said. â€œThis should have been the first thing we took up.â€

Steilâ€™s bill isnâ€™t the only stock trading ban thatâ€™s been introduced.

Fitzpatrick had endorsed a bipartisan bill last year sponsored by Reps. Chip Roy (R-Texas) and Seth Magaziner (D-R.I.), dubbed the â€œRestore Trust in Congress Act,â€ that would bar lawmakers, their spouses, dependent children and trustees from owning, buying or selling individual stocks.

Rep. Anna Paulina Luna (R-Fla.) had introduced a discharge petition to force a vote on Roy and Magazinerâ€™s bill; however, leadership ended up advancing Steilâ€™s bill, dubbed the â€œStop Insider Trading Act,â€ through committee.

Trump urged members of Congress during his speech on Tuesday to pass Steilâ€™s legislation â€œwithout delay.â€

Luna, referencing Trumpâ€™s speech, wrote onÂ the social platform X, â€œPASS THE STOP INSIDER TRADING ACT NOW!â€

â€œThis is going to be a great vote. Banning insider trading needs to happen!â€ Luna wrote in a follow-up tweet.

Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) told reporters on Wednesday that Steilâ€™s bill will get a House vote â€œsoon,â€ according toÂ Bloomberg News.

But complicating matters for Johnson is whether he has enough votes for the bill to pass.Â 

Johnson is currently operating with a 218-214 majority, meaning he can afford only one Republican defection and still pass party-line legislation. Virtually every Democrat will oppose Steilâ€™s bill because the minority party is pushing for any ban to include the president, vice president and their families.

Rep. Tim Burchett (R-Tenn.) said heâ€™s leaning towards opposing Steilâ€™s bill, which he argues falls short of addressing the issue. He also said he doesnâ€™t see the Senate taking up the bill, even if it did pass the House.

â€œI think if they do, theyâ€™re going to pass something thatâ€™s totally different than what we have,â€ Burchett said. â€œAnd we donâ€™t agree on it, and then they all giggle and laugh in both parties as it fails and they continue on their insider stock trading.â€

When asked why thereâ€™s been a stalled effort on a stock trading ban overall, Burchett said, â€œglaciers sprint past Congress.â€

â€œWe move at a very record slow pace,â€ he said. â€œWe always have, since Iâ€™ve been there under Democrats and under Republicans.â€

Fitzpatrick said he would support Steilâ€™s bill because he believes itâ€™s â€œincremental progress,â€ but he added that he doesnâ€™t think it goes â€œfar enoughâ€ to â€œfix the system.â€

Meanwhile, House Democrats introduced a discharge petition last month to force action on a bill banning members of Congress, the president, the vice president and their immediate families from owning, holding and trading stocks. Magaziner had introduced the bill last year, with support from House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.).

Democrats have blasted Steilâ€™s bill, arguing that it doesnâ€™t extend to the executive branch and allows members to still sell their existing stocks.

â€œI want something to be very clear: That this bill that has been introduced by Republican leadership is not a congressional stock trading ban,â€ Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) told reporters last month. â€œIt was written by and for the absolute wealthiest members of Congress to look like they are passing a ban, but â€¦ it actually creates a ton of new [avenues] by which they can own, buy and sell stock in even greater shadows from public opinion. â€¦ They can call it whatever they want, but it is not a stock trading ban.â€

data.title: The big new controversy over the Epstein files, explained
data.description:
When the Department of Justice released more than 3 million pages of documents relating to the convicted sexual predator Jeffrey Epstein on Jan. 30, the sheer volume of the material was dizzying.

It always seemed plausible that important elements of the release would take time to emerge as reporters and researchers dug into the massive trawl.

This is exactly what has happened. Major news outlets this week picked up on reporting, which first came from an independent journalist, about potentially vital documents that appear not to have been made publicly available.

Itâ€™s a complicated story. Hereâ€™s what you need to know.

What is the core of the controversy?

Documents outlining three of four FBI interviews apparently related to a woman who accused President Trump, as well as Epstein, of sexually assaulting her decades ago, seem to be missing from the latest release.Â 

The woman made the claims in 2019, but they date back to the 1980s, when she was a minor.

Her allegation against Trump is uncorroborated. The president has denied all wrongdoing in relation to his friendship with Epstein, which ended roughly two decades ago.

Also, The Guardian late on Thursday published a story in which it said its reporters had obtained the missing documents and that the womanâ€™s claims â€œat times appear outlandish.â€

Whatâ€™s the broader explanation?Â 

The latest release of the Epstein files includes a 2021 catalogue of material provided to Ghislaine Maxwellâ€™s legal team.Â 

Maxwell, Epsteinâ€™s sometime-girlfriend, was tried and convicted of sex trafficking charges at the end of that year. The data set lists â€œnon-testifying witness material.â€

It includes anonymized reference to four interviews relating to one person, who has the case number 3501.045.

Of those four interviews, only one appears to have been publicly released.Â 

In that interview, the woman makes detailed allegations of rape by Epstein but makes no allegation of abuse against Trump.Â 

The president is mentioned only in relation to a friend sending the woman a photograph. In her interview with FBI agents, the woman notes she still has this photo saved in her cellphone messages but asks if she can crop it so it shows only Epstein.

When she was asked why she wanted to crop the photo, she hesitated, and the notes reflect that her â€œattorney advised [she] was concerned about implicating additional individuals, and specifically any that were well known, due to fear of retaliation.â€ The photo, according to the FBI account of the interview, was â€œa widely distributed photographâ€ of Epstein and Trump.

The strand of the Epstein story centering on this woman was first brought to light by independent journalist Roger Sollenberger.

Sollenberger, and subsequently outlets including NPR, The New York Times and CNN, have traced details about the woman in question that match a woman who made the serious but unproven allegation of sexual assault against Trump.

Some commentators have pointed to the fact that four interviews took place as a sign that investigators believed the woman to be credible. But her credibility would not, in itself, prove any specific claim to be true. Furthermore, The Guardianâ€™s story noted that it had â€œidentified a woman matching the biographical details in the FBI records. She has faced several fraud and theft charges in Washington and, in 2023, a felony charge for the exploitation of an elderly person in Georgia. It is not clear how those cases were resolved.â€

What does the DOJ and the White House have to say?

The Department of Justice (DOJ) is adamant that it has done nothing wrong and is not hiding anything for nefarious reasons.

In one social media post earlier this week, the DOJ said that â€œNOTHING has been deleted.â€ The post asserted: â€œALL responsive documents have been produced unless a document falls within one of the following categories: duplicates, privileged, or part of an ongoing federal investigation.â€

This has not quelled disquiet around the story, however.

The Hill reported on Thursday that several Republican senators were putting pressure on the DOJ to release all possible files. Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.), asked whether material containing this womanâ€™s allegations should be held back, replied: â€œI donâ€™t know how else to say it: Release the documents.â€

On Wednesday, the DOJ said that it was conducting a review because â€œseveral individuals and news outlets have recently flagged files related to documents produced to Ghislaine Maxwell.â€Â 

It added that if any file was discovered to have been kept out of the public eye when it should not have been, â€œthe Department will of course publish it, consistent with the law.â€

Trump has not addressed this specific element of the controversy in any in-depth way, but, speaking with reporters last week, he claimed he had â€œbeen totally exoneratedâ€ in the Epstein matter.Â 

White House statements to multiple news outlets this week have echoed that claim.

What about Democrats?

Democrats, especially those serving on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, which has been probing the Epstein matter, have been scathing.

On Wednesday, the House Oversight Democratsâ€™s account on the social platform X asserted: â€œThe Department of Justice continues to change its story. The facts are clear: documents related to a survivor who accused Donald Trump and Jeffery Epstein of abuse when she was a minor are missing from the released files.â€Â 

Rep. Robert Garcia (D-Calif.), the committeeâ€™s ranking member, told MS NOW on Tuesday that he had gone to the Department of Justice in person to probe the matter further.

â€œThose additional documents seem to be missing,â€ Garcia said, â€œand thatâ€™s something that I confirmed as of yesterday in my visit to the Department of Justice. The idea that there is a possible cover-up or that we are hiding actual documentation of an alleged crime by the President of the United States â€¦ is incredibly serious.â€

Where does the story go from here?

The focus on the story has become so intense that pressure for disclosure of the interview notes is intense. However, the new reporting from The Guardian may dilute at least some of that pressure.

Meanwhile, the problem for those pressing for disclosure is, if the DOJ says it has valid reasons for not making the interviews public, it is hard to definitively prove them wrong.

data.title: Trump looms large in Texas as GOP gears up for Senate primary
data.description:
President TrumpÂ is loomingÂ large over Texas as the Lone Star Stateâ€™s GOP gears up forÂ competitive primaries next week.Â 

The president is set to stop in Corpus ChristiÂ on Friday, just days after his State of the Union address and as Texas voters cast their ballots inÂ a high-stakes, three-wayÂ Republican primaryÂ race for Sen. John Cornynâ€™s (R-Texas) seat in the Senate.Â Â 

WhileÂ Trump is visiting theÂ state in an official capacity,Â observers are eager to seeÂ if the president has anything to say about the closely watched primary, with Texas Democrats feeling increasingly optimistic about their chances in November.Â Â 

Trump told reportersÂ earlier this month that he was taking a â€œserious lookâ€ at endorsing in the Texas Senate race. Two weeks later, he said he was still undecided,Â even asÂ heÂ issued supportÂ for several other candidates in the state.Â 

â€œI like all three ofÂ them, actually. Those are the toughest races.Â Theyâ€™veÂ all supported me.Â Theyâ€™reÂ all good,â€ Trump said on Feb. 17. â€œYouâ€™reÂ supposed to pick one, soÂ weâ€™llÂ see what happens. But I support all three,â€ the president said of the primaryâ€™s leading candidates.Â 

Cornyn, seeking a fifth term in the Senate, is lockedÂ in a competitive race with Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R) and Rep. Wesley Hunt (R-Texas)Â â€” all three of whom have flexedÂ theirÂ conservativeÂ bonaÂ fidesÂ and underscored their alignment with the president.Â Â 

â€œWhen you have aÂ 24-yearÂ incumbent U.S. senator and you donâ€™t endorse him, thatâ€™s a pretty bigÂ tell toÂ the electorate, especiallyÂ a Texas ruby red primary electorate, oneÂ Republican strategist, referring to Cornyn, told The Hill.

â€œItâ€™s not an endorsement against Cornyn,â€ the strategist added. â€œButÂ when you have the president and your fellow junior senator [Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas)] not willing to endorse you in the primary, people get that and primary voters get that.â€Â Â 

All three contenders areÂ slatedÂ to attend Trumpâ€™s Friday remarks in Corpus Christi, with Paxtonâ€™s campaign reportedly rescheduling a planned event so the Texasâ€™ attorney general can see the president ahead of the March 3 contest.

Paxton boasts a 1-point lead over Cornyn â€” withÂ 34 percent and 33 percent, respectively â€”according to Decision Desk HQâ€™sÂ polling aggregate. But neither appears poised to secure the support they need to win the primary outright.Â Hunt, whose bid has been seen as a longshot, is pulling inÂ roughly 20Â percentÂ support.Â Â 

If no candidate wins over 50 percent of the vote on Tuesday, the race will head to a May 26 runoff between the top two vote-getters.Â Â 

â€œAround the primary, the number one issue appears to be: who can differentiate themselves as the closest to the president?â€ Josh Blank, research director for the Texas Politics Project at the University of Texas at Austin, told The HillÂ last week.Â 

â€œIf they have an endorsement,Â thatâ€™sÂ the best-case scenario,â€ he continued. â€œBut outside of that,Â youâ€™reÂ seeing a lot of advertisements that show, in one way or another, that candidateâ€™s closeness to the president, or even just the presidentâ€™s orbit.â€Â Â 

A Trump endorsement could be aÂ game-changerÂ in the close race, though experts say that the possibility of one coming before the primary is increasingly unlikely as Tuesday nears.Â Â 

Texans have already started to vote, and an endorsement may be more likely after the primary, especially if it tips into the expected runoff.

While Democrats are outpacing Republicans in earlyÂ voteÂ turnout,Â GOP turnout is higherÂ than past years.Â Â 

AccordingÂ to CNN, early turnout on the GOP side is 15 percent higher than it was at this point in 2022.Â Â 

â€œThese are pretty high number for Republicans too, which conceivably could help Cornyn, but whenÂ you get to a runoff in Texas, itâ€™s a much more constricted,Â more redder, much more conservative voting bloc,â€Â theÂ GOP strategist said.Â Â 

If Trump weighed in, â€œit absolutely would affect Republican primary votersâ€™ choices,â€ James Dickey, a former Texas GOP chair, said.

Blank, though, suggested that Trumpâ€™s backing may not hold as much weight in the Senate race as in other Texas contests, since GOP voters are largely engaged in the race and both leading candidates, whom have won statewide elections, have their own faithful bases.

And, although Trump has longÂ been a kingmakerÂ in Republican primaries, he had a notable slipup in the state earlier this month. The president endorsed the Republican candidate in aÂ special election runoffÂ for Texasâ€™s ninth stateÂ Senate district â€” but theÂ Democrat contenderÂ overperformed, winningÂ theÂ seat byÂ roughly 14Â points.Â Â 

Cornyn, who told NBC News that he spoke to Trump aboutÂ a possible endorsement last month, has warned of a â€œmassacreâ€ for the GOP in Texas if Paxton gets the nod, pointing toÂ controversyÂ around the state attorney general.Â Paxton was impeachedÂ by the Texas House in 2023 on corruption charges, then later acquitted by the state Senate.Â 

Republicansâ€™ national Senate campaign arm has made a similar case. In a February memo, argued that Cornyn is â€œthe only Republican candidate who reliably wins a general electionÂ matchup.â€Â 

AndÂ Senate Majority Leader John Thune (R-S.D.) also told Semafor earlier this month thatÂ heâ€™sÂ cautioned Trump â€œmany timesâ€ on consequences for the party if CornynÂ isnâ€™tÂ the Texas Senate GOP nominee.Â 

The warnings come as Republicans have raised concerns overÂ theirÂ support among Hispanic voters, including in Texas.Â AccordingÂ toÂ VoteHubÂ data cited in the Texas TribuneÂ earlier this month, 79 percent of Hispanic voters backed the Democrat in the state Senate District 9 special election this month. Â 

Paxtonâ€™s team, however, has emphasized his double-digit wins in past elections, as well as his lead over Cornyn in the polls.Â Â 

Meanwhile, a spokesperson for Huntâ€™s team last week blasted national Republicansâ€™ â€œmisguided investment in a 24-year incumbent.â€Â Â 

Fridayâ€™s trip is Trumpâ€™s firstÂ public event since delivering his State of the Union address on Tuesday, where heÂ acknowledged the devastating flooding that tore through the state last year as part of a wide-ranging speech on his administrationâ€™s accomplishments.Â Â 

â€œPresident Trump looks forward to returning to the great State of Texas this week to discuss the economy and tout his â€˜Drill Baby Drillâ€™ agenda,â€ White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said in a statement to The Hill.Â Â 

Even if an endorsement in the Senate raceÂ doesnâ€™tÂ come before Tuesdayâ€™s primary, Trumpâ€™s presence will be closely watched asÂ Texas kickâ€™s off the midterm cycle with primaries up and down the ballot.Â Â 

â€œIâ€™m never one to try to [predict] what the President will or will not do, butâ€¦he will be in Corpus Christi [Friday],â€ Texas Republican Vinny Minchillo consultant told The Hill via email. Â â€œDoes he endorse? And who?Â IfÂ itâ€™sÂ Cornyn IÂ donâ€™tÂ believe it will be enough to help him avoid a runoff.â€Â Â

data.title: Wesley Hunt points to Vance, Scott in defending missed votes
data.description:
Rep. Wesley Hunt (R-Texas) on Thursday defended his missed votes in the House by pointing to Senate votes missed by Sen. Tim Scott (R-S.C.) and Vice President Vance when he represented Ohio.

Hunt was questioned about his voting record in an appearance on â€œThe Will Cain Showâ€ on Fox News. Host Will Cain said Hunt was the most absent member of Congress and did not attend the State of the Union. Hunt said in his defense that he has been running his campaign for a Senate seat all across Texas.

â€œDo you know how many votes JD Vance missed when he was campaigning to be vice president? All of them,â€ Hunt said. â€œDo you know how many votes Tim Scott missed when he was running for president? The third-most in the history of the Senate, over 150.â€

â€œSo again, this is a moot point,â€ he continued. â€œEverybody knows that when youâ€™re running for higher office, itâ€™s important to get your face in front of the people.â€

Hunt added that when on flights, he voted for â€œconsequential pieces of legislation.â€

Between November and February, Hunt has missed 69 out of 158 votes, according to the nonpartisan Congress-tracking website GovTrack. Vance missed 111 votes in the Senate after he was picked to be President Trumpâ€™s running mate in July 2024, GovTrackâ€˜s data shows. Scott missed 110 votes in the Senate between April 2023 and December 2023, though he ran for president from May to November of that year.

In December, Bloomberg reported that the senator with the third-most missed votes in 2025 was Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), who missed 58 of 659 votes. Sen. Thom Tillis (R-N.C.) ranked at No. 2, with Sen. Ruben Gallego (D-Ariz.) in the top spot.

Hunt was third in the University of Texas/Texas Politics Project Poll behind Texas Attorney GeneralÂ Ken PaxtonÂ and incumbent Sen.Â John Cornyn. Hunt trailed at 26 percent, with Paxton and Cornyn statistically tied at 36 percent and 34 percent, respectively.

All three will face each other in the upcoming primary election on March 3.

data.title: US military shot down border patrol drone with laser in Texas, lawmakers say
data.description:
The U.S. military shot down a Customs and Border Protection (CBP) drone with a laser in Texas on Thursday, according to Democratic lawmakers, prompting the closure of airspace near the U.S.-Mexico border.Â 

Democratic Reps. Rick Larsen (Wash.), Bennie Thompson (Miss.) and Andre Carson (Ind.) said in a jointÂ statementÂ Thursday evening that the Pentagon reportedly shot down a CBP drone using â€œhigh-risk counter-unmanned aircraft system.â€Â 

The trio criticized the White House â€œsidesteppingâ€ a bipartisan bill to train drone operations and address the lack of communication between the Department of Homeland Security, Pentagon and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).Â 

â€œNow, weâ€™re seeing the result of its incompetence,â€ they said in a statement.Â 

The incident prompted the FAA toÂ close the airspace near Fort Hancock, Texas.Â 

The FAA told The Hill that a temporary flight restriction (TFR) was already in place around the Fort Hancock area and has been expanded include a â€œgreater radius to ensure safety.â€ The TFR does not impact commercial flights. Â 

The Hill has reached out to the Pentagon, CBP and the White House for comment.Â 

The incident marks the second time this month that a laser was used in Texas and caused a closure of airspace. The CBP used a laser, lent by the Pentagon, to fire in the airspace near Fort Bliss, causing the FAA to shut down air traffic at the El Paso airport.Â 

Sen. Tammy Duckworth (D-Ill.), the ranking member on the Senateâ€™s Aviation Subcommittee, said the situation is â€œalarmingâ€ and demanded a â€œthorough, independentâ€ investigation.Â 

â€œAs Ranking Member of the Aviation Subcommittee, I will be calling on the Inspectors General of the Departments of Defense, Transportation and Homeland Security to launch a joint investigation into the recent scandals in El Paso and now Fort Hancock,â€ Duckworth said in a statement Thursday night.Â

data.title: Vance: 'No chance' any Iran strikes would lead to long war in Middle East
data.description:
Vice President Vance on Thursday defended the U.S. potentially launching military strikes on Iran, saying there was â€œno chanceâ€ that it would lead to a longer war in the Middle East.

Vance said in an interview with The Washington Post that the strikes would be a deterrent to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon unless the issue is solved diplomatically.

â€œThe idea that weâ€™re going to be in a Middle Eastern war for years with no end in sight â€” there is no chance that will happen,â€ he said.

The vice president said he does not know how President Trump will act on Iran, saying that he and the president are â€œskeptic[s] of foreign military interventions.â€

Vance chuckled when the Post asked if he, given the Marine veteranâ€™s past criticisms of the Iraq War, could have seen himself as part of an administration interested in bringing about regime change. He said that life â€œhas all kinds of crazy twists and turnsâ€ and said Trump is an â€œAmerica First president.â€

â€œI do think we have to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past,â€ Vance added. â€œI also think that we have to avoid overlearning the lessons of the past. Just because one president screwed up a military conflict doesnâ€™t mean we can never engage in military conflict again. Weâ€™ve got to be careful about it, but I think the president is being careful.â€

Vance reiterated that the administration prefers a diplomatic outcome to the current standoff. But, he said, that â€œdepends on what the Iranians do and what they say.â€

Tensions have risen between leaders in Washington, D.C., and in Tehran over Iranâ€™s nuclear program. Trump has threatened Iran with military action over the program, despite previously claiming the U.S. â€œobliteratedâ€ itÂ during strikes against the countryÂ in June.

The president also threatened military actions over the governmentâ€™s crackdown on dissent following massive anti-government protests last month.

The administration has amassed a major military contingentÂ in the Middle East amid negotiations, with Trump previously saying he is considering a limited strike.

Iranâ€™s Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has warned of retaliation if the U.S. were to strike. Iranian officials have argued that its nuclear program is for peaceful purposes, claiming that uranium enrichment is a national right.

Talks on Thursday in Oman showed â€œsignificant progress,â€ according to Omani Foreign Minister Badr al-Busaidi.

Some congressional lawmakers plan to hold a vote on aÂ war powers resolutionÂ to block Trump from carrying out strikes on Iran without approval from Congress.Â Democrats largely back the bipartisan call for a resolution, co-led by Reps. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.) and Thomas Massie (R-Ky.).

Republican Rep. Warren Davidson (Ohio) joined Massie in pledging to support the resolution. He argued that â€œno case has been madeâ€ in favor of striking Iran.

House Democrats have said they will force a vote to limit the presidentâ€™s war powers next week.

data.title: Tampa man killed in Cuban boat shootout wanted to overthrow island's government, loved ones say
data.description:
TAMPA, Fla. (WFLA) â€” The family and friends of Michel Ortega Casanova said he was one of four men killed in an armed confrontation off the Cuban Coast.

The Cuban government claims 10 men were on a boat registered in Florida that tried to invade their coast.

The Cubans said they intercepted the boat and a shootout resulted. Four men on the boat were killed while six others were wounded and taken into custody.

U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio, who is also Cuban American, said the U.S. government is conducting their own investigation into the incident because it does not trust the Cuban version of events.

Thursday, the Cuban Ministry of the Interior identified the individuals as:

  • Cristian Ernesto Acosta Guevara
  • Conrado Galindo Serrior
  • JosÃ© Manuel RodrÃ­guez CastellÃ³
  • LeordÃ¡n Cruz Gomez of Tampa
  • Amijail Sanchez Gonzalez
  • Roberto Alvarez Avila
  • Pavel Alling PeÃ±a
  • Michael Ortega Casanova of Tampa
  • LediÃ¡n PadrÃ³n Guevara
  • Hector Duani Cruz Correa

The last four people on the list were said to be deceased. The others are in Cuban custody.

According to the Cuban government, weapons were found on the boat, including â€œassault rifles, sniper rifles, pistols, Molotov cocktails, multiple assault equipment including night vision equipment, bulletproof vests, assault bayonets, camouflage clothing, ammunition of various calibers, food for combat use, means of communication, and a large number of monograms of counterrevolutionary terrorist organizations.â€

The statement continued:

â€œRight from the start, Cuban authorities have been in touch with their U.S. counterparts, including the State Department and the Coast Guard, about this terrorist attempt. An investigation is underway to clarify the facts with the utmost rigor. The Cuban government is willing to exchange information with the US government on this matter. Among other requirements, we will request information on those involved, the means used, and other details from the US authorities through the mechanisms in place between the two countries.â€

NOW PLAYING

The U.S. government is not confirming any of this information.

Angela Chaviano with Casa Cuba in Tampa said Michel Ortega Casanova was a member of their organization and visited just last week.

â€œMichel is a great friend, great, is like a brother, and it was very painful for me to know that he was one of the ones deceased,â€ Chaviano said.

According to The Associated Press, Michelâ€™s brother, Misael Ortega Casanova, said his brother had fallen into an â€œobsessive and diabolicalâ€ quest to overthrow the Cuban government. He lived in the U.S. for over 20 years and became a citizen.

Misael Ortega Casanova said his brother worked as a trucker and is survived by his wife, his mother, two sisters, and a daughter who is pregnant.

â€œNo one knew,â€ Misael Ortega Casanova said. â€œMy mother is devastated.â€

â€œThey became so obsessed that they didnâ€™t think about the consequences nor their own lives,â€ he added.

Chaviano said Michel Ortega Casanova hoped to overthrow the Cuban Government and tried to recruit others to join him.

â€œI know that he was always saying that the only way to make a change was through arms, was through force and not just by talking,â€ Chaviano said.

NOW PLAYING

She said Leordan Enrique Cruz GÃ³mez was also on the boat from Florida and was wounded in the exchange of gunfire.

Tampa attorney Ralph Fernandez has long fought for Cuban political prisoners.

â€œTampa is deeply penetrated with Cuban intelligence, meaning they have actual intelligence officers in the network and agents in place in the network,â€ Fernandez said.

He said the Cuban government knew when and where to expect Michel Ortega Casanovaâ€™s boat and that they were armed.

â€œTheyâ€™ll be able to determine why there was a Cuban gunboat waiting for them in a region where they donâ€™t service that coastline,â€ Fernandez said. They donâ€™t have the fuel or the manpower to service that coastline.â€

According to the Monroe County Sheriffâ€™s Office, the boat was reported stolen by a resident who said he saw his boatâ€™s registration numbers being reported by Cuban media.
